thread.title: Top Gear host Matt Le Blanc forced to eat HORSE WILLY as well as other gross 'delicacies' in new series of car show

author: Hayley Minn
title: Top Gear host Matt Le Blanc forced to eat HORSE WILLY as well as other gross 'delicacies' in new series of car show
text:
Top Gear host Matt Le Blanc forced to eat HORSE WILLY as well as other gross 'delicacies' in new series of car show BBC bosses are finding ways of getting the former Friends star to boost ratings Share Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Top Gear host Matt Le Blanc is going to be forced to eat a HORSE WILLY in the upcoming series of the BBC show. 
After Top Gear’s revamp with Chris Evans hit the skids last series, producers are trying to boost viewing figures by coming up with gross new challenges for the former Friends star and his co-hosts Rory Reid and Chris Harris. 
As well as horse penis, the Top Gear hosts are going to try “delicacies” such as sheep ears and a pig’s face when they head to Kazakhstan. 
Chris told the Daily Star: “The weirdest thing I saw? Read More Top Gear host Matt LeBlanc uses Avtoros Shaman to rescue naked ramblers in trailer for new series Matt LeBlanc is going to eat horse willy on Top Gear (Photo: BBC) 
“I saw Matt try and eat part of a horse that was used in some sort of reproductive process and give up quite early on.” 
Rory added: “The strangest thing I ate was a pig’s face. 
“And brain. And ears.” 
The new series will feature Strictly Come Dancing winner Ore Oduba and former Celebrity Big Brother star Frankie Dettori. 
And Matt, Chris and Rory are getting equal billing when it returns on March 5, after a ratings slump forced Chris to quit the driving seat. Read More Top Gear's Matt LeBlanc reveals what happened when his daughter met Prince Harry Matt, Rory and Chris will be returning to Top Gear in March (Photo: PA) 
But Matt has warned that the chemistry between the trio might take longer to heat up than a frozen windscreen in winter. 
Matt said: “For the three guys that were on the show before us, it took them a while to build up a rapport. 
“This is the first season for the three of us, and it does take a little while. Everyone is open to getting along but it takes a little while to speed up the shorthand. 
“We are now getting to a point where we are starting to click.” 
*Top Gear returns to BBC Two on Sunday March 5 at 8pm Like us on Facebook
